title: Exclusive: Ireland's Orange Order discourages protests over Brexit deal
text:
BELFAST (Reuters) - The head of Northern Ireland’s influential Orange Order said on Sunday unionists in the province should avoid staging violent protests over British Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal despite feeling that they had been let down.

FILE PHOTO: Members of the Ballynafeigh Orange Lodge march away from the security barrier on the Ormeau Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland July 12, 1999. The Security Barriers were put in place overnight preventing the Orange Order from parading though the nationalist Catholic lower Ormeau Road. REUTERS/PAUL MCERLANE/File Photo

The deal struck with EU leaders last week has been met by fierce opposition from pro-British politicians in the region, including Johnson’s Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) allies, who say it weakens Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom.

“There is a feeling people need to do something but I would be encouraging people that it isn’t a case for street protest at this time,” Orange Order Grand Secretary Mervyn Gibson told Reuters in a telephone interview.

“I wouldn’t like to see loyalist violence. I think this is a time for cool heads, and violence only plays into the hands of republicanism,” he said.

The 30,000-member Orange Order, a Protestant organisation, is central to the culture for Northern Irish loyalists - named for their allegiance to the British throne - and will strongly influence whether unionists take to the streets in big numbers to protest.

Gibson, a Presbyterian minister whose society holds annual parades that often raise tensions between Irish nationalist Catholics and pro-British Protestants, said there is “something wrong” when people in Northern Ireland must fill in customs forms and those in Scotland, England and Wales, the other parts of the United Kingdom, do not.

A 1998 peace accord largely ended three decades of sectarian and political conflict in Northern Ireland, referred to as the “Troubles”, that cost some 3,600 lives, including some in attacks in mainland Britain and Ireland.

The border between EU member Ireland and Northern Ireland has been open as a part of that accord, but this has created a dilemma over how to avoid reinstating a hard border once Britain leaves the bloc, something that the EU believes would be jeopardise peace.

Under the proposed Brexit deal, Northern Ireland would remain in the United Kingdom’s customs area but tariffs would apply on goods crossing from mainland Britain to Northern Ireland if they were deemed to be headed further, to Ireland and the bloc’s single market.

But the DUP’s hopes of persuading pro-Brexit members of Johnson’s Conservative Party to join them in opposing the deal may prove a longer shot if those lawmakers believe it will not fan unrest and put Northern Ireland’s fragile peace at risk.

Many unionist politicians, including DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds are members of the Orange Order.

“I think we have been let down by him (Boris Johnson), badly. It’s a deal that could see us sleepwalk in to a united Ireland. He hasn’t understood the unionist position, it wasn’t until now people are beginning to realise that,” Gibson said.

“This deal needs a unionist response from across the board. Parts of the deal need to be changed because this deal isn’t a good deal for unionism. It orientates us to Dublin economically and we are an integral part of the United Kingdom so should be treated as such.”

‘DON’T NEED UNREST’

Britain’s Northern Ireland Minister Julian Smith said on Sunday that he had “good calls with unionist community leaders” and would continue to speak to them as he pledged to fight for Northern Irish interests during the next Brexit phase.

Smith’s comments followed a report by Sky News on Saturday quoting an unnamed source as saying loyalist groups had met to consider their response to the deal, including the possibility of “civil disobedience on a large scale”.

However that was dismissed on Sunday by the leader of the Progressive Unionist Party (PUP), a small loyalist political party with links to the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) and Red Hand Commando.

Slideshow (2 Images)

Those two groups waged bombing campaigns during the “Troubles” before putting down their weapons. Backed by church leaders last year, they said they were turning their backs on criminality and would expel members who engage in activities such as drug dealing and racketeering.

“I am not hearing it, I haven’t heard anything about unrest,” PUP leader Billy Hutchinson, a former UVF prisoner who is one of the party’s four local councillors in Northern Ireland, told Reuters.

“People are unhappy for a number of reasons, they don’t like the idea of Northern Ireland being half in and half out... I can’t speak for every person in society but from my point of view we don’t need unrest, we need unionism to act as one and have a united voice.”
description: The head of Northern Ireland's influential Orange Order said on Sunday unionists in the province should avoid staging violent protests over British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal despite feeling that they had been let down.
